title: Miyakejima
meta_title: Miyakejima Volcano — Eruption History, Caldera & Facts | VolcanoAtlas
meta_description: Miyakejima is a 775 m active stratovolcano island 200 km south of Tokyo. Famous for its 2000 eruption and toxic gas emissions. Full history and facts.

quick_answer.what: Miyakejima is an active stratovolcano forming a circular 8 km wide island in the northern Izu Islands, approximately 200 km south-southwest of Tokyo, Japan.
quick_answer.status: Active — last erupted in 2010. The 2000 eruption created a 1.6 km wide summit caldera and forced the evacuation of all 3,800 residents for nearly 5 years.
quick_answer.famous_for: The dramatic 2000 eruption and caldera collapse, and the prolonged volcanic gas crisis that kept the island evacuated until 2005.
quick_answer.danger_level: High — approximately 2,500 residents live on the island, which has experienced devastating eruptions roughly every 20–60 years.

key_facts_box.tectonic_setting: Subduction zone — Pacific Plate beneath Philippine Sea Plate (oceanic crust < 15 km)
key_facts_box.summit_caldera: 1.6 km wide, formed during 2000 eruption by subsidence

overview.content: Miyakejima is an active basaltic stratovolcano forming a circular, 8 km wide island in the northern Izu Islands, approximately 200 km south-southwest of Tokyo in Japan. Rising roughly 1,100 m from the seafloor, the island reaches 775 m (2,543 ft) above sea level and is home to approximately 2,500 residents who live in communities encircling the volcano's base. Miyakejima has a remarkably prolific eruption history, with 40 recorded events spanning from prehistoric times to 2010. The volcano is best known internationally for its dramatic 2000 eruption, which created a 1.6 km wide summit caldera through subsidence and forced the complete evacuation of the island's 3,800 residents. Toxic sulfur dioxide emissions from the new caldera kept the island largely off-limits until 2005, and residents still carry gas masks as a precaution. The volcano's basaltic composition produces eruptions dominated by flank fissure activity — lava flows often reach the coast, sometimes entering the sea and extending the island's shoreline. Located along the Izu Volcanic Arc where the Pacific Plate subducts beneath the Philippine Sea Plate, Miyakejima is part of the same volcanic chain that includes Izu-Oshima and Hachijojima. Its position within Tokyo Prefecture, despite being 200 km from the capital, places it under the administrative oversight of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government.

geology_and_formation.content: Miyakejima rises from the northern portion of the Izu Volcanic Arc, generated by the westward subduction of the Pacific Plate beneath the Philippine Sea Plate. The volcano is built primarily of basaltic lavas and pyroclastic deposits, reflecting its oceanic crustal setting where mantle-derived melts ascend with relatively little crustal contamination. The island's circular outline reflects the symmetrical growth of the stratovolcano from a central vent, though the summit has been repeatedly modified by caldera formation. A major caldera approximately 3.5 km wide formed during a powerful eruption about 2,500 years ago. Since the end of a three-century eruption hiatus around 1469 CE, the volcano's eruptive style has been dominated by radially oriented fissure eruptions on the flanks, sometimes accompanied by minor summit activity. Numerous craters, vents, and maars (explosion craters formed by groundwater-magma interaction) are scattered across the flanks and coastal areas. The 2000 eruption fundamentally altered the summit: caldera subsidence created a 1.6 km wide, approximately 450 m deep depression that has since partially filled with rainwater.

eruption_history_overview.content: Miyakejima's 40 recorded eruptions span from approximately 6450 BCE to 2010, with historical records from 1085 CE onward. The volcano has produced at least six VEI 4 eruptions in prehistoric and early historical times, demonstrating significant explosive capability. Since the end of a ~300-year hiatus in 1469, eruptions have occurred with a recurrence interval of roughly 20‐60 years. The eruption style since 1469 has shifted predominantly to flank fissure eruptions, often producing lava flows that reach the coast. Major eruptions in 1643, 1712, 1763, 1874, 1940, 1962, 1983, and 2000 each caused significant damage to the small island community, including destruction of homes, farmland, and infrastructure.

subsections.title: The 1763 Eruption — VEI 4 with Maar Formation
subsections.content: The 1763 eruption was one of Miyakejima's most explosive historical events, rated VEI 4. Activity occurred at both the summit (Oyama) and on the south-southwest flank, where the Shinmio maar was created by violent phreatomagmatic explosions when rising magma encountered groundwater. The eruption caused significant destruction on the island and produced pyroclastic surges that affected coastal areas.

subsections.title: The 1983 Eruption — Lava Flows Destroy Ako Village
subsections.content: The October 1983 eruption (VEI 3) was one of the most destructive events in modern Miyakejima history. A 4.5 km long NE–SW fissure opened on the southwest flank, producing vigorous lava fountaining and fast-moving lava flows. The flows advanced rapidly toward the southwest coast, engulfing and destroying much of Ako village, including approximately 400 buildings. Remarkably, no fatalities occurred thanks to successful evacuation, but the physical and economic damage was extensive. The eruption provided dramatic visual evidence of the risks of living on a small volcanic island.

subsections.title: The 2000 Eruption — Caldera Collapse and Mass Evacuation
subsections.content: The 2000 eruption transformed Miyakejima and became one of the most closely studied volcanic events in Japanese history. Beginning in late June with seismic unrest, the eruption evolved through several phases. Initial activity involved submarine eruptions off the western flank and magma intrusion that triggered felt earthquakes. By July, phreatomagmatic explosions from the summit intensified, and the summit area began subsiding as magma drained laterally. Over the following weeks, a 1.6 km wide caldera formed through incremental subsidence, eventually reaching approximately 450 m in depth. Repeated explosive eruptions from the new caldera sent ash columns to over 15 km altitude, depositing ash on the Japanese mainland. By September 2000, all 3,800 island residents were evacuated. The eruption was followed by an even more prolonged crisis: massive sulfur dioxide emissions from the caldera — reaching 50,000 tonnes per day at peak — created toxic gas concentrations that prevented resettlement until February 2005. Even today, residents carry gas masks, and parts of the island remain in restricted high-gas zones.

current_status_and_monitoring.content: Since its last minor eruption in 2010 (VEI 1), Miyakejima has been in a state of declining but ongoing volcanic degassing. Sulfur dioxide emissions from the 2000 caldera have gradually decreased from their peak of 50,000 tonnes per day but continue at levels that require monitoring and precautions. JMA operates an extensive monitoring network on the island including seismometers, tiltmeters, GPS, gas sensors, and web cameras. Volcanic alert levels remain at Level 1 (normal) during quiet periods. The caldera lake that has formed in the 2000 depression continues to deepen as rainwater accumulates, raising concerns about future phreatic activity if volcanic heat interacts with the growing lake volume.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content: Living on Miyakejima requires constant awareness of volcanic hazards. The primary risks include lava flows from flank fissure eruptions (which have historically reached the coast within hours), pyroclastic surges from phreatomagmatic explosions, ashfall, and volcanic gas — particularly sulfur dioxide, which remains an ongoing concern from the 2000 caldera. The island's compact size (~55 km²) means that no community is more than 4 km from the summit, and evacuation by sea or air is the only option. JMA and the Tokyo Metropolitan Government maintain evacuation protocols, gas monitoring stations throughout the island, and shelters equipped with gas filtration. Residents are required to carry portable gas masks at all times. The island's approximately 2,500 residents accept these risks for the fishing, tourism, and community lifestyle the island provides.

geography_and_physical_description.content: Miyakejima is a nearly circular island approximately 8 km in diameter, covering about 55 km². The summit, Oyama, reaches 775 m (2,543 ft) and is now dominated by the 1.6 km wide caldera formed in 2000, which has partially filled with a turquoise-colored acidic lake. The flanks are dissected by numerous historical lava flows that have created a rugged, dark-colored coastal landscape where aa lava meets the sea. Forests of Japanese cedar and subtropical vegetation cover the lower and middle slopes where they have not been destroyed by recent eruptions or gas damage. Communities, a small airport, and port facilities ring the island's coast. The island lies approximately 200 km SSW of Tokyo and is accessible by ferry (approximately 6 hours) or small aircraft.

cultural_significance.content: Miyakejima occupies a unique place in Japanese volcanic culture as a community that has repeatedly rebuilt after devastating eruptions. The 2000–2005 evacuation became a national story of resilience, as islanders maintained their community identity in temporary housing on the mainland before returning to their volcanic home. The island is administratively part of Tokyo Prefecture — making it one of Tokyo's most unusual communities. Today, Miyakejima has reinvented itself partly through volcano tourism: guided tours of the 2000 caldera, the stark landscape of gas-damaged forests, and the island's rich birdlife (including the endangered Izu thrush) draw visitors. The island's experience with volcanic gas management has become a case study in long-term coexistence with volcanic hazards.

nearby_volcanoes.content: Miyakejima is part of the northern Izu Volcanic Arc, a chain of volcanic islands extending south from the Izu Peninsula toward the Mariana Islands. Its nearest volcanic neighbor is Mikurajima to the south, while Izu-Oshima, the most frequently active volcano in the chain, lies approximately 60 km to the north. Hachijojima, another inhabited volcanic island, is approximately 100 km to the south. The entire Izu arc is one of Japan's most active volcanic regions and forms part of the broader Ring of Fire system.

facts: The 2000 eruption forced the complete evacuation of all 3,800 residents for nearly 5 years — one of the longest volcanic evacuations in modern Japanese history.
At its peak, the 2000 caldera emitted approximately 50,000 tonnes of sulfur dioxide per day, making it one of the strongest volcanic gas sources on Earth.
Miyakejima residents still carry portable gas masks at all times as a precaution against toxic sulfur dioxide emissions from the 2000 caldera.
Despite being 200 km from downtown Tokyo, Miyakejima is administratively part of Tokyo Prefecture and governed by the Tokyo Metropolitan Government.
The 1983 eruption destroyed approximately 400 buildings in Ako village when lava flows from a 4.5 km fissure reached the southwest coast.
The 1.6 km wide summit caldera created in 2000 was formed not by explosion but by gradual subsidence as magma drained laterally through underground conduits.
Miyakejima has erupted roughly every 20–60 years since 1469, creating a predictable but dangerous cycle for island residents.
The island's volcanic gas crisis generated one of the world's most sophisticated real-time gas monitoring and public alert systems.
A growing turquoise-colored acidic lake in the 2000 caldera raises new concerns about future phreatic explosions.
Miyakejima is home to the endangered Izu thrush (Turdus celaenops), one of Japan's rarest songbirds, which has adapted to the volcanic landscape.

faqs.question: Is Miyakejima safe to visit?
faqs.answer: Miyakejima is open to visitors, though volcanic hazards require awareness. Residents and tourists must carry portable gas masks, as sulfur dioxide concentrations can spike in certain areas. Some parts of the island near the summit remain in high-gas restriction zones. JMA monitors the volcano continuously, and the island has an extensive gas alert system. Ferry and air services from Tokyo operate regularly. Guided volcano tours, hiking, diving, and birdwatching are popular activities.

faqs.question: What happened during the 2000 Miyakejima eruption?
faqs.answer: The 2000 eruption began in late June with seismic unrest and evolved into a complex event. Submarine eruptions occurred off the western flank, followed by summit explosions and gradual caldera subsidence. A 1.6 km wide caldera formed as magma drained laterally, and explosive eruptions sent ash columns above 15 km altitude. All 3,800 residents were evacuated by September 2000. Massive sulfur dioxide emissions then prevented return until February 2005. It was one of Japan's most significant volcanic crises of the modern era.

faqs.question: Why do residents need gas masks on Miyakejima?
faqs.answer: Following the 2000 eruption, the newly formed summit caldera began emitting enormous quantities of sulfur dioxide, peaking at 50,000 tonnes per day. Although emissions have declined significantly, SO2 concentrations still occasionally reach dangerous levels, particularly in low-lying areas during calm atmospheric conditions. An island-wide monitoring system tracks gas levels in real time, and alarms sound when concentrations exceed safety thresholds. Residents carry masks as a precaution against sudden gas concentration spikes.

faqs.question: How do you get to Miyakejima from Tokyo?
faqs.answer: Miyakejima is accessible from Tokyo by overnight ferry (approximately 6 hours from Takeshiba Pier in central Tokyo) or by small aircraft from Chofu Airport in western Tokyo (approximately 50 minutes). The island has a small airport and a port facility. Ferry services run regularly but can be canceled in rough weather. The island is administratively part of Tokyo Prefecture despite being approximately 200 km to the south-southwest.

faqs.question: When will Miyakejima erupt again?
faqs.answer: The exact timing cannot be predicted, but Miyakejima's historical eruption pattern — roughly every 20–60 years since 1469 — suggests another eruption is possible within the coming decades. The most recent eruption was in 2010 (minor, VEI 1), and major eruptions occurred in 1983 and 2000. JMA monitors the volcano continuously for precursory signs including increased seismicity, ground deformation, and changes in gas emissions.

faqs.question: How big is Miyakejima island?
faqs.answer: Miyakejima is a nearly circular island approximately 8 km in diameter, covering about 55 km² (roughly 21 square miles). The summit of the volcano, Oyama, reaches 775 m (2,543 ft) above sea level, though the total edifice rises approximately 1,100 m from the seafloor. Approximately 2,500 people live in communities around the island's coast, primarily engaged in fishing, agriculture, and tourism.
